page.title: 20LOCAL HISTORY-2
page.content: The Underhill family were connected with both Oxhill and Idlicote from 1450 to 1667.Whatcote was called Quatecote at one time but the modern name is supposed to be derived from the Whattle and Daub construction of the original cottages.It lies on a long straight road of at least Roman origin.It had the reputation of being the poorest village,but the church has Norman features. The public house is reputed to have been built as the ale house for the church builders in Norman times and it was there that{Oliver Cromwell}stayed before the {Battle of Edgehill.}Oxhill was mainly for the{Roundheads}although some local families fought for the {Royalist Cause}under Lord Compton. Some land in Whatcote is still owned by the Marquis of Northhampton.
